author: majkinetor
body:
`Stop-Job` can take a long time or forever depending on what you have started. See for example [this](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/19248149/powershell-stop-job-takes-too-long) or [this](https://github.com/Badgerati/Pode/issues/553).

Adding `-Force` should bring it down imediatelly.

`Remove-Job` has force param but it still hangs.

comments.author: NoMoreFood
comments.body: @majkinetor Can you a standalone, easily reproducible example snippet here?

comments.author: Badgerati
comments.body:
Hi @NoMoreFood,

I've come across this recently when using Jobs for Sockets/HttpListener. A simple example is:

```powershell
Start-Job -Name Example -ScriptBlock {
    $listener = [System.Net.HttpListener]::new()
    $listener.Prefixes.Add('http://127.0.0.1:8080/')
    $listener.Start()
    $listener.GetContext()
}
```

Calling `Stop-Job -Name Example` will just hang forever, or take 5mins+ to stop on some machines. `Remove-Job -Name Example -Force` exhibits the same issue as well.

(edit: changed the prefix so the example runs as non-admin as well)

comments.author: majkinetor
comments.body:
Note that this must be executed in admin shell or it will just complete with 'Access denied'. 

Note also that it doesn't only avoid stopping, but also completelly renders Powershell session unusable.

title: Feature Request: Force stop/remove-job
